snippet: Researchers who took core samples from reefs off the coast of Panama found that the reefs effectively experienced a growth hiatus during a period of climatic extremes.
abstract: Dr Richard B Aronson study in journal Science finds that coral reefs off the coast of Panama stopped growing about 4,000 years ago due to rising sea temperatures, and did not recover for 2,500 years; researchers say phenomenon may have parallels to the current effect of global warming on reef health.
lead_paragraph: Researchers who took core samples from reefs off the coast of Panama found that the reefs effectively experienced a growth hiatus during a period of climatic extremes.

headline.print_headline: Coral Shows Resilience In Face of Hostile Climate
headline.seo: Coral Rebounded From Hostile Climate Millenniums Ago, Study Suggests
headline.main: Coral Shows Resilience in Face of Hostile Climate
